claim: If you type your PIN number backwards at an ATM, a notification will be sent to the police.

supporting.text: There is no widely documented or mainstream evidence that ATMs are programmed to send police notifications when a PIN is entered backwards.

attacks.text: There is no widely documented or mainstream evidence that ATMs are programmed to send police notifications when a PIN is entered backwards.
Some ATMs may have custom security features, including PIN reversal detection, as part of their programming.
Even if some ATMs have such features, they are not standardized or publicly documented, making widespread implementation unlikely.
Urban legends and anecdotal reports suggest that certain banks or regions might have implemented this feature.
Urban legends are unreliable sources of information and lack verifiable evidence.

supporting.text: ATM security systems are designed to detect incorrect PIN entries by locking the card after a certain number of failed attempts, not by monitoring reversed inputs.

attacks.text: ATM security systems are designed to detect incorrect PIN entries by locking the card after a certain number of failed attempts, not by monitoring reversed inputs.
Some banks have implemented additional security measures, including monitoring for reversed PIN entries as part of fraud detection protocols.
Even if some banks monitor reversed PIN entries, this is not a standardized feature across all ATM systems, making the original claim unreliable as a general statement.
There have been documented cases where reversed PIN entries triggered silent alarms in certain high-security ATM systems.
These documented cases are rare and typically involve specialized ATMs in high-risk areas, not standard consumer banking machines.

supporting.text: Banking and financial institutions prioritize fraud detection through transaction patterns and unusual activity, not through reversed PIN entry.

attacks.text: Banking and financial institutions prioritize fraud detection through transaction patterns and unusual activity, not through reversed PIN entry.
Some banks have implemented specific fraud detection mechanisms for reversed PIN entry as an additional security layer.
Even if some banks implement reversed PIN detection, it is not a standardized or widely adopted practice across the banking industry.
Reversed PIN entry can be a signal of duress, prompting banks to notify authorities as part of their customer safety protocols.
Duress signals are typically handled through separate mechanisms (e.g., silent alarms or specific code words), not reversed PINs.

supporting.text: Police notifications from ATMs would require integration with law enforcement systems, which is not a standard feature of ATM software.

attacks.text: Police notifications from ATMs would require integration with law enforcement systems, which is not a standard feature of ATM software.
Some ATMs in high-crime areas or specific jurisdictions may have custom software that includes law enforcement integration.
Even in high-crime areas, the cost and complexity of such integration would make it rare and non-standard.
ATM manufacturers could include this feature as a security option, even if it is not widely adopted.
Without regulatory mandates or widespread demand, ATM manufacturers have little incentive to develop such features.

supporting.text: Publicly available banking security guidelines and ATM operation manuals do not mention any functionality related to reversed PINs triggering police alerts.

attacks.text: Publicly available banking security guidelines and ATM operation manuals do not mention any functionality related to reversed PINs triggering police alerts.
Some banks may implement undocumented security features not mentioned in public guidelines.
Undocumented security features would violate banking transparency regulations in most jurisdictions.
ATM manufacturers could build this functionality as a hidden security measure.
Hidden security features in ATMs would require regulatory approval and oversight.
